ref.mixed-citation: Donald M. MacKinnon , Borderlands of Theology and Other Essays (:J. B. Lippincott,1968),14. He immediately suggests that metaphysics may be “almost an attempt to destroy poetry by converting it into syllogism … as … we reach the ultimate.” Ibid. I shall disagree that poetry is necessarily destroyed in the conversion but may remain vibrant and indeed be revisited in the future.

My longer-term project, to unfold in another venue, will be to specify and describe certain “way stations” on the passage from poetry to logic, otherwise conceived more abstractly as a path from similarity to sameness. Such “way stations” are, of course, reifications to aid analysis since the pathway is continuous. Initially, I would posit a progression from metaphor to analogy to models to concepts—the last of which are logically manipulable. However, thought can enter at any point along such a continuum and move in either direction. One can find additional support for this stance, I suggest, in Peirce's sign theory with its emotional, energetic, and logical interpretants.

For purposes of this exercise, I will: (a) treat MacKinnon's question as a proposition, (b) substitute “logic”simpliciterfor “logically admissible” for the sake of crispness, and (c) delete “sometimes” for the sake of a universal metaphysics.

Velleman makes a cogent case, in a seminal essay, that a meaningful and integrated life requires the reconciling of both rational and emotional self-understandings. The former comes from philosophy, science, and possibly theology. The latter springs from narratives appealing to our stored emotional patterns, which are diachronic in that from arousal to resolution they trace an arc of beginning, middle, and end. It is this rather than any causal connectedness in plot that gives narrative its unique explanatory force as we focus on the end of the total story and assimilate it to the familiar life narrative each of us spins. Sallie McFague employs the “root-metaphor” approach in her metaphorical theology and acknowledges ( Metaphysical Theology ,201) that the term originated in Stephen C. Pepper 's World Hypotheses (:University of California Press,1942),84–114. There Pepper sees the skilled theoretician as examining one area of existence and, via analogy guided by common sense, generating a set of basic explanatory concepts, that is, categories. He or she then develops and refines those in the process of attempting to apply them in other areas. These concepts must persist in close adherence with their energizing root metaphor or risk becoming empty abstractions. At their most comprehensive, the theories generated from root metaphors become world hypotheses. Pepper deems only four of these as “relatively adequate”: formism, mechanism, contextualism, and organicism.

Accentuating this movement from feeling to logically-informed action, Raposa writes regarding Peirce's method of inquiry that it “commences with an act of interpretation, a reading of signs that are presented in human experience, proceeds with the exploration and clarification of that interpretation and then with its utilization as a rule for living, a habit of action.” Ibid.,144.

Peirce contended that metaphysics results from the operation of the normative sciences, whereas I maintain that those sciences constitute the very dynamic of the metaphysical enterprise. MacKinnon's question implies agreement with the latter position, which holds that metaphysics ranges across the entire continuum and cannot limit itself to the resultant concepts if it claims to examine all of reality. I suggest that Peirce realized this in an analogous fashion when he stressed scrutinizing the total content of our consciousness (phaneron) and not just that which points to external phenomena (MS 908).

“If metaphysics is necessary, it is because man, a moral being, needs a metaphysics in order not to despair of the sense of life:” Jean Lacroix , Maurice Blondel, Sa Vie, Son Oeuvre (:Presses Universitaires de France,1963),66–71.

We should be alert, however, to an overhanging threat. The assaults of the postmodernists against sameness have deteriorated universals and undermined the very process of generalization itself. As a consequence, philosophers may revert to poets, permanently shunninglogica docensforlogica utensin an atavistic retrogression.
